On September 16, 2017, Atlanta United broke the MLS single-match attendance record previously held by LA Galaxy by selling more than 69,256 tickets for their match against Orlando City SC.

The official attendance for the Atlanta United vs. Orlando City SC match on September 16, 2017, was 70,425, making Atlanta the first MLS team to surpass 70,000 in attendance for a non-doubleheader match.
On October 22, 2017, Atlanta United broke the MLS single-match attendance record again with an official attendance of 71,874 for their match against Toronto FC.
Atlanta United finished the 2017 season with an average attendance of 48,200 for MLS regular season games, higher than English clubs Everton and Chelsea.
On March 11, 2018, Atlanta United set a new league single-match attendance record by selling 72,035 tickets for their home opener against D.C. United.
On June 30, 2018, Atlanta United had an attendance of 71,932, more than any other soccer game in the world that day, including the 2018 FIFA World Cup matches.
Atlanta United set the league single-match attendance record again on July 15, 2018, with 72,243 in attendance.
In 2018, Atlanta United became the first MLS team to average more than 50,000 in attendance for the regular season, with an average attendance of 53,002.
Atlanta United won its first MLS Cup on December 8, 2018, before a crowd of 73,019, the largest non-doubleheader crowd in league history.
On August 3, 2019, Atlanta United set another single-match attendance record with 72,548 in attendance for their match against the LA Galaxy.

In 2016, the Fort Lauderdale Strikers announced they were moving out of Lockhart Stadium, leading to the stadium's disrepair before Inter Miami announced intentions in January 2019 to use the site for their training ground and a new 21,550-seat stadium.
The Fort Lauderdale city council unanimously approved Inter Miami's bid for the Lockhart Stadium site in March 2019.
On July 9, 2019, the Fort Lauderdale City Commission unanimously approved a 50-year lease agreement for the Lockhart Stadium site with Inter Miami.
Inter Miami's stadium was branded as DRV PNK Stadium in April 2021 following a naming rights agreement with AutoNation.
A second expansion completed in January 2024 increased DRV PNK Stadium's capacity to 21,550 seats.
Inter Miami began playing in Fort Lauderdale in March 2020 and will continue to do so until the Miami Freedom Park stadium is completed.
The Miami Freedom Park project, including a 25,000-seat stadium, was approved by roughly 60% of voters in a public referendum held on November 6, 2018.
Miami-Dade Circuit Judge Mavel Ruiz preserved the results of the November referendum, allowing city administrators to negotiate a 99-year lease with Inter Miami's ownership for Miami Freedom Park.

The Miami Freedom Park development, associated with Inter Miami CF, is planned to include 1,000,000 square feet of office, retail, and commercial space, 750 hotel rooms, 23 acres of public soccer fields, and a 10.5-acre stadium.
The club owners of Inter Miami CF will make annual installments of $20 million for 30 years for improvements to public parks across the city as part of the Miami Freedom Park development.

Before settling on the Melreese site for Miami Freedom Park, locations considered included Dodge Island at PortMiami (2013), the Downtown Miami waterfront at Museum Park (2014), a site adjacent to MLB's Marlins Park (2015), and a privately owned site in Miami's Overtown (2015–16).
Beckham announced in June 2019 that Freedom Park was proposed to launch in 2022, but the stadium is now projected to open in the 2025 MLS season.
Construction of Miami Freedom Park began in August 2023, with the current projection of completion being 2026.
Inter Miami CF announced in January 2019 its intentions to use the Lockhart Stadium site in Fort Lauderdale as the club's training ground for its first team, youth academy, and future USL team.
The Florida Blue Training Center, Inter Miami CF's training facility, covers 30 acres and includes a park, youth soccer fields, a community center, and seven training fields.
The Florida Blue Training Center includes the 5,000-seat AutoNation Sports Field, which has been the home ground of Major League Rugby club Miami Sharks since their debut in 2024.

Inter Miami CF announced a partnership with Brightline in April 2022 to provide passenger trains from Miami and West Palm Beach to Fort Lauderdale station with a dedicated shuttle for fans, named the GOOOL Getter, for home matches.
The original ownership group of the franchise now known as Miami Freedom Park LLC was led by Marcelo Claure and formed in 2013.
Masayoshi Son and brothers Jorge and Jose Mas joined the Miami Freedom Park LLC ownership group in 2017.
David Beckham negotiated an option to own an MLS expansion team at a discounted franchise fee when he signed with LA Galaxy in 2007.
On September 17, 2021, Beckham and the Mas brothers bought out Marcelo Claure and Masayoshi Son's stakes in the ownership group.

The official logo for CF Montréal was revealed on August 6, 2011, during a match between the NASL Montreal Impact team and the NSC Minnesota Stars.

In January 2021, the club rebranded to Club de Foot Montréal (CF Montreal) and introduced new official colours: "Impact Black", "Ice Grey", and "Sacré Bleu".

The rebranding of Montreal Impact to CF Montreal in 2021 was poorly received by the club's main supporter group, the Ultras, leading to a protest in front of Saputo Stadium.

St. Louis City Soccer Club began play in Major League Soccer in 2023.
St. Louis City SC is a member of the Western Conference in Major League Soccer.
The team plays its home matches at Energizer Park, located across from Union Station in Downtown West.
St. Louis City SC was established in 2019 as an MLS expansion team.
In 2007, St. Louis was considered as a possible destination for Real Salt Lake.
Jeff Cooper led attempts to bring an MLS expansion team to St. Louis from 2008 to 2009, but the bids were turned down.
AC St. Louis, a second division men's club launched by Jeff Cooper, played only one season before folding in 2011.
MLS Commissioner Don Garber mentioned in 2015 that any possible expansion to St. Louis would occur after 2020.
The St. Louis Rams moved to Los Angeles in 2016, which initially accelerated talks of an MLS expansion team in St. Louis.
In 2017, a proposed ownership group in St. Louis sought public funds to help build a $200 million soccer-specific stadium next to Union Station.
Voters rejected a funding plan for the stadium in an April 4, 2017, referendum.
Carolyn Kindle and other heirs to the Enterprise Rent-A-Car fortune re-launched St. Louis's MLS bid in October 2018 without seeking public funding.
The Board of Aldermen's Housing, Urban Development, and Zoning Committee approved the stadium plan on November 28, 2018.
Purina became the first jersey sponsor and founding partner of St. Louis City SC on March 31, 2021.
Together Credit Union became the second founding partner and the official banking partner of St. Louis City SC on July 14, 2021.
St. Louis City SC's stadium, Energizer Park, is located in downtown St. Louis and is part of a 31-acre development area.
The ownership group of St. Louis City SC is notable for being the first female majority-owned team in MLS, led by Carolyn Kindle and female members of the Taylor family.
The St. Louligans, founded in 2010, is the oldest active soccer supporters' group in the St. Louis area.
St. Louis City SC's new stadium includes a supporters' section designed for more than 3,000 standing spectators.
St. Louis City SC defeated the Chicago Fire for the first time on May 11, 2024, with a score of 3-1.
The Vancouver Whitecaps were established as an MLS team on March 18, 2009.
The Whitecaps began play in Major League Soccer in 2011 as the 17th team.
The Whitecaps became the first Canadian team to qualify for the MLS Cup playoffs in the 2012 season.
The Vancouver Whitecaps have won the Canadian Championship four times: in 2015, 2022, 2023, and 2024.
The Whitecaps reached the CONCACAF Champions Cup final once, in 2025, where they lost to Cruz Azul.
The Whitecaps' first match in the MLS era was on March 19, 2011, against Toronto FC, which they won 4-2.
Eric Hassli scored the first goal in the Whitecaps' MLS era.
Teitur Thordarson was confirmed as the head coach for the Whitecaps' inaugural MLS season on September 2, 2010.
Teitur Thordarson was relieved of his duties on May 30, 2011, after the Whitecaps won just one of their first twelve matches.
Tom Soehn replaced Teitur Thordarson as the head coach on an interim basis on May 30, 2011.
The Whitecaps attracted 15,500 season ticket holders in their first MLS season.
The Whitecaps were eliminated by Tigres UANL with a 4–1 aggregate scoreline in both the 2016–17 and 2024 editions of the CONCACAF Champions Cup.
The Whitecaps defeated the Portland Timbers 5–0 in the wild-card round of the playoffs in the 2024 regular season.
The Whitecaps were eliminated by Los Angeles FC in Round 1 of the playoffs in the 2024 regular season.
The Whitecaps were eliminated in the Round of 32 of the 2024 Leagues Cup by Pumas UNAM.
The Whitecaps won the 2024 Canadian Championship by defeating Toronto FC 4–2 on penalties after a scoreless draw.
The Whitecaps officially announced they would continue using the "Whitecaps" name with a redesigned logo on June 8, 2010.
The official club colours of the Whitecaps are navy blue ("deep sea"), white, and light blue ("Whitecaps blue").
The Whitecaps unveiled a third kit that is predominantly "arbutus brown" with sky blue accents on June 14, 2012.
The Whitecaps used a redesigned version of their 1979 kit as a 40th anniversary tribute in 2019.
The Whitecaps unveiled the Bloodlines Jersey in 2023, highlighting a partnership with Telus to support Canadian Blood Services.
The Whitecaps released The 50 Jersey on the club's 50th anniversary in 2024, creating a modern twist on the original crest from 1974.
BC Place, the home stadium of the Whitecaps, underwent a major renovation between 2009 and 2011, which included the installation of the world's largest cable-supported retractable roof.
The Whitecaps played their final match at Empire Field on September 24, 2011.
The Whitecaps played their first match at BC Place on October 2, 2011.
The National Soccer Development Centre on the UBC campus, partnered with the Whitecaps, opened on September 22, 2017.
During the COVID-19 pandemic, the Whitecaps played most of their 2021 home matches at Rio Tinto Stadium in Sandy, Utah.
The Whitecaps supporters group known as the Southsiders began in 1999.

Rain City Brigade, another Whitecaps supporters group, was established in 2010.
The Vancouver Whitecaps' first all youth supporter group is called Vancouver Albion, and they are located in section 254.
The Prawnsiders became formally organized at the beginning of the inaugural MLS season in 2011.
The name "Prawnsiders" is derived from the term "prawn-sandwich brigade," which is used to describe soccer supporters who sit in the more expensive seats.
South Sisters, a group for Vancouver Whitecaps supporters who identify as female, LGBTQ2+, or allies, was officially formed in 2019.

The official mascot for the Vancouver Whitecaps is Spike, a Belted kingfisher.

Vancouver's first game in MLS was against Toronto FC, marking the beginning of a rivalry intended by the league to spur competition between the two Canadian teams.
